questions.text: Which of the following is not a Differential Diagnosis of ADPKD
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Congenital megaureter The differential diagnosis of ADPKD includes Option: A. Autosomal recessive PKD, Tuberous sclerosis complex, Von Hippel–Lindau disease Option: B. Renal cysts and diabetes syndrome (RCAD), Option: D. Oro-facial-digital syndrome type 1, Medullary sponge kidney Simple renal cysts

Highyeild:

Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is the most common autosomal prevalent genetic cystic renal disease causing chronic renal failure requiring dialysis and renal transplantation. It occurs due to mutation in one of two genes (PKD1 on chromosome 16 and PKD2 on chromosome 4). ADPKD has variable penetration, and approximately 50% of affected individuals eventually develop end-stage renal disease (ESRD). Risk factors (ESRD) Early age of presentation Hypertension Male sex ADPKD gene 1 African ethnic group. Clinical Presentation : ADPKD is associated with cysts in other organs, such as the liver, pancreas, arachnoid membranes, and seminal vesicles. It usually manifests at 30, and in some patients, it is never diagnosed. Renal symptoms include abdominal pain, haematuria, or a palpable mass. Treatment : Most patients older than 20 years are hypertensive, and reasonable blood pressure control can delay the progression to renal failure. Novel agents such as vasopressin antagonists (tolvaptan), somatostatin analogs, and mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) inhibitors have shown a potential to prevent cystogenesis, cyst expansion, and declining renal function. Complications : Intracranial aneurysms occur in approximately 10–30% of patients with ADPKD; subarachnoid hemorrhage may cause sudden death in young adults.

Extraedge:

Kidney cysts always precede liver cysts, and their prevalence in adult polycystic kidney disease increases with age. In those younger than 20 years, the prevalence of liver cysts is 0%, whereas in those older than 60 years, it is 80%.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of left flank pain. The patient has had two episodes of urolithiasis during the last year. He initially had pain with urination that improved with oxycodone. Over the past day, the pain has worsened, and he has also developed a fever and chills. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He does not drink alcohol. His current medications include metformin and lisinopril. The patient appears ill and uncomfortable. His temperature is 39.1 degrees C (102.3 degrees F), the pulse is 108/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 90/62 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Examination of the back shows left costovertebral angle tenderness. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. Laboratory studies show Ultrasound shows enlargement of the left kidney with a dilated pelvis and echogenic debris. A CT scan shows a 16-mm stone at the left ureteropelvic junction, dilation of the collecting system, thickening of the wall of the renal pelvis, and signs of perirenal inflammation. Intravenous fluid resuscitation and intravenous ampicillin, gentamicin, and morphine are begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Percutaneous nephrolithotomy The 16 mm calculus at the ureteropelvic junction has caused urinary tract obstruction (UTO; dilated collecting system!) and severe pyelonephritis (signs of shock). Fluid resuscitation and antibiotic therapy would address pyelonephritis and urosepsis, but if acute UTI is not treated, the patient will develop acute kidney injury, which has a high mortality rate. Percutaneous nephrolithotomy, which requires only minimal anesthesia, is indicated to rapidly decompress the renal collecting system until a more definitive therapy for the renal stone can be performed. Early decompression is required because an untreated acute UTO can result in permanent kidney injury.

Highyeild:

Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy PCNL involves the removal of renal stones by creating a track between the skin and the pelvicalyceal system. Typically, this procedure is done in a prone position. Fluoroscopy, or US, is used for localization. The posterolateral calyx is commonly chosen for entry. The In conjunction with pneumatic and laser lithotripsy, US is the most common energy source used. Complications include bleeding, infection, and pleural violation in cases of supracostal puncture. Severe bleeding may require selective angioembolization. Indications for percutaneous nephrolithotomy Renal stones >2 cm. Lower pole renal stones with anatomy that is unfavorable for SWL. It failed SWL or RIRS for renal calculi. Staghorn calculi. Contraindications to percutaneous nephrolithotomy Pregnancy. Untreated UTI. Bleeding diathesis. Current anticoagulation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Ureteroscopy and stent placement are viable options for decompressing the renal collecting system in patients with UTO. However, in hemodynamically unstable patients such as this, a method that requires less anesthesia and provides more rapid and reliable decompression is preferable. Option: C. Shock wave lithotripsy may be used to treat renal calculi that are larger than 10 mm, which is the case in this patient. However, manipulating the calculus in any way can result in life-threatening sepsis in a patient with urolithiasis and a concomitant UTI. Therefore, definitive stone management must be deferred until the UTI is treated. Option: D. Nephrectomy and antibiotic therapy is the recommended first-line therapy for patients with severe emphysematous pyelonephritis and signs of acute renal failure or septic shock. This patient's diabetes mellitus and UTO are risk factors for emphysematous pyelonephritis, which would be indistinguishable from severe acute pyelonephritis. However, the absence of gas within the renal parenchyma and collecting duct system on abdominal CT suggests that this patient does not have emphysematous pyelonephritis.

Extraedge:

Miniaturized PCNL (e.g., mini-perc) involves using smaller access tracks. The standard PCNL access track is >28Fr compared with miniaturized versions using <22Fr ways. Miniaturized PCNL is most useful in patients with a smaller stone burden and children.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of left flank pain for 2 hours. The pain is colicky; he describes it as 8 out of 10 in intensity. He has nausea and has vomited once. He had a similar episode 6 months ago for which he took naproxen. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He is a second-year medical student and has been consuming more coffee and energy drinks than normal to stay awake and study for the past two days. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He takes no medications. His temperature is 37.3 degrees C (99.1 degrees F), his pulse is 98/min, and his blood pressure is 124/78 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. Examination of the back shows no costovertebral angle tenderness. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Urinalysis is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction Though most cases of ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction are diagnosed in early childhood, less severe cases may initially present in early adulthood, usually after ingesting large amounts of alcohol or coffee. These beverages increase diuresis and, in the context of UPJ, cause hydronephrosis as a large amount of urine overwhelms the narrowed UPJ. This manifests as episodic flank pain, as seen in this patient.

Highyeild:

Ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction, also often called pelvic ureteric junction (PUJ) obstruction, describes an incomplete and intermittent reduction in urine flow from the kidney to the proximal ureter. Incidence : Occurs in 1 in 1000 live births with a male and left-sided predominance. It is the most common cause of severe antenatal hydronephrosis. Pathology : Commonly a disruption of circular muscle or collagen fibers in the proximal ureter results in an intrinsic narrowing near the renal pelvis. Extrinsic compression is less common and results from an aberrant renal vessel compressing the ureteropelvic junction. Presentation / Diagnosis : Most cases are diagnosed in the postnatal evaluation of an antenatally detected hydronephrosis. However, some newborns present with an abdominal or flank mass and a history of urinary tract infection or haematuria. Older children may present with severe intermittent fank or abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting, known as Dietl’s crisis. MAG-3 imaging confirms the diagnosis, and knowing the differential renal function helps to decide between surgical and non-surgical management

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Bilateral renal cysts are seen in patients with adult polycystic kidney disease. Though patients with ADPKD can also present with flank pain (secondary to cyst rupture, bleeding, or infection), they also tend to have early-onset hypertension, renal insufficiency, and a positive family history of polycystic kidney disease. Option: B. Glomerular IgA deposits are seen in IgA nephropathy (Berger disease). IgA nephropathy generally presents as episodic haematuria 1-3 days following an upper respiratory infection. Intermittent flank pain, as seen in this patient, is not a characteristic symptom of IgA nephropathy. Option: C. Posterior urethral valves are usually diagnosed prenatally or in the first months of life. Typically, neonates will present with recurrent UTIs secondary to increased bladder pressure and subsequent vesicoureteral reflux. It would be scarce for symptoms to initially appear at this patient's age.

Extraedge:

99mTc Mercaptoacetyltriglycine (MAG3) is now the radiopharmaceutical of choice used in the assessment of patients with suspected upper urinary tract obstruction, such as UPJ obstruction 99mTc diethylenetriaminepenta-acetate (DTPA) was used previously in patients suspected of having UPJ

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He says he feels well but is worried because his 32-year-old brother recently had to start hemodialysis because of kidney disease. He reports that his grandfather had "bad kidneys” as well. The patient does not have dysuria, haematuria, or flank pain. He has no history of serious illness. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. An ultrasound of his right kidney is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Reassurance The ultrasound shows a simple renal cyst, a benign, asymptomatic lesion rarely requires treatment. If the cyst had features potentially indicating malignancy (wall irregularity, multilocular appearance, presence of septae) or were causing symptoms such as impaired urinary flow or pain, further management would be shown. However, as this patient is asymptomatic, reassurance is the appropriate next step.

Highyeild:

Renal Cyst : Types: Sporadic, Acquired, and Genetic Bosniak renal cyst classification is used to grade cysts and the probability of malignancy. Category I cysts represent benign lesions that require no further follow-up. Category II cysts can be safely followed up. Categories III and IV have a higher probability of malignancy and require surgical excision. APKD : ADPKD – autosomal dominant, systemic disease: Rarely manifests before the fourth decade Hypertension, abdominal pain, haematuria, or a palpable fank mass are common presentations. Control of hypertension can delay its progression.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Percutaneous aspiration would be an appropriate treatment for a symptomatic renal cyst. As this patient is asymptomatic, with no symptoms of fever, flank pain, or haematuria, there is no indication of aspiration. Option: C. Genetic testing for a PKD1 mutation would be used to screen for autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease in an asymptomatic individual with a positive family history. While this patient has a family history of unspecified kidney disease, ultrasound has only shown a simple solitary cyst in a kidney of average size. Patients with ADPKD typically have enlarged kidneys with multiple cysts of varying sizes, making this an unlikely diagnosis. Option: D. An abdominal CT scan would be performed if findings on the initial ultrasound were unclear, calcifications or septae were seen, or multiple renal cysts were visibly clustered in a pattern that could mask an underlying carcinoma. This patient's ultrasound shows a solitary round, sharply demarcated, hypoechoic lesion, meaning that additional imaging is unnecessary.

questions.correct_answer: C. The superior mesenteric artery prevents ascent of the kidney
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The superior mesenteric artery prevents ascent of the kidney Urogram shows a horseshoe kidney-flower vase sign. The inferior mesenteric artery prevents the ascent of the kidney

Highyeild:

This is the most common renal fusion anomaly, occurring in about 1 in 400 live births with a male predominance. The isthmus lies at the level of the fourth to fifth lumbar vertebrae (fused lower poles). This causes failure to ascend and rotate so the renal pelvis faces anteriorly and vertically, with the malrotation calyces pointing posteromedially. The vascular supply is variable, and the ureter may insert high on the renal pelvis. Presentation: Most horseshoe kidneys (HSKs) are asymptomatic but associated with increased genital anomalies, PUJ obstruction (PUJO), and stone formation. The incidence of Wilms’ tumor is higher in HSK.

questions.text: A 40-year- female presents with complains of abdominal pain, burning micturition, fever, and loss of weight . On examination abdomen is soft , no tenderness , guarding or rigidity. On further evaluation diagnosed as renal tuberculosis. Which of the following is the earliest change in the renal kidney?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Papillary necrosis If bacterial multiplication goes unchecked, caseous necrosis results in the formation of tubercles

Highyeild:

Genitourinary tuberculosis (GUTB) accounts for 15–20% of extrapulmonary cases of TB Pathology: GUTB occurs as a result of either reinfection or reactivation of old TB granulomas. Blood-borne organisms are deposited close to the glomeruli, causing an inflammatory reaction. Macrophages react, and granulomas are formed. If bacterial multiplication goes unchecked, caseous necrosis results in the formation of tubercles. Multiple tubercles coalesce and rupture into the collecting system, causing intermittent tuberculous bacilluria and pyuria Presentation : Renal Function Loss Diagnosis : Urine Culture - Sterile Pyuria in acidic Urine NAAT CTU Management: Short Course ATT(Rifampicin, isoniazid, and pyrazinamide are used sometimes with ethambutol as first-line drugs) DJ Stenting PCN Nephrectomy

0 % malignant The above-given condition comes under Category I cyst of Bosniak renal cyst classification as there are Thin hairline septations with fine calcifications seen in the wall of right kidney No soft tissue component enhancement

Highyeild:

Bosniak renal cyst classification depends on the characteristics of the cyst wall, septae, solid component and enhancement on contrast administration It is used to grade cysts and probability of malignancy Category I cysts represent benign lesions that require no further follow-up Category II cysts can be safely followed up Category III cysts have a risk of malignancy of 30–100% and should undergo a biopsy to identify those patients requiring surgery.
